title: Statistics using R
text:
Star on GitHub



SARA is a not-for-profit organization in India. To know more about SARA, kindly vist our website.
This course aims to help the participants to overcome the fear of numbers, statistics and coding.

It is a five days annual residential training program to learn basics of statistics using R programming language.
Priority admission for marginalized communities and women.
The course is free. Participants only pay for their food and accommodation.

Email us at sara.institute.info@gmail.com \(\cdot\) Call us at 925 315 2024.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 1

Install required packagesLoad libraries



install.packages("tidyverse") # Includes readr for importing
install.packages("janitor") # For cleaning column names
install.packages("lubridate") # For date handling




library(tidyverse)

library(janitor)

library(lubridate)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
section: Step 2. Basic CSV Import with read_csv()
text:
Step 2. Basic CSV Import with read_csv()
 
df <- read_csv("path/to/file.csv")

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 3. Understanding read_csv() Parameters

col_names: Specify if first row contains column names
skip: Skip rows at the beginning
n_max: Read only first n rows
na: Specify what values should be treated as NA
col_types: Specify column types explicitly

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 4. Cleaning Column Names
ü§Ø Problem: Column names with spaces, special characters, or inconsistent cases are hard to work with

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 5. Converting Data Types

Convert character to factor
Convert character to date

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 6. Working with Factors

Factors are categorical variables with defined levels
They‚Äôre useful for:

Ensuring valid categories
Controlling sort order
Statistical modeling

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Exporting Cleaned Data

Export to CSV
Export to Excel

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Reading other File Formats

Excel files (requires readxl package)
SPSS, Stata, SAS files (requires haven package)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Tips and Best Practices

Use read_csv() instead of read.csv()

It‚Äôs faster and creates tibbles
Better type detection

Clean column names immediately

Use janitor::clean_names()
Consistent naming makes code easier

Be explicit about data types

Use col_types parameter
Convert to factors where appropriate

Document your cleaning steps

Comment your code
Keep track of what you changed and why

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Common Problems & Solutions

PROBLEM 1: Column names with spaces or special characters

SOLUTION: Use clean_names() or backticks (Column Name)

PROBLEM 2: Wrong data types after import

SOLUTION: Specify col_types in read_csv() or use mutate()

PROBLEM 3: Dates imported as character -SOLUTION: Use lubridate functions (ymd, mdy, dmy)
PROBLEM 4: Mixed encodings or special characters

SOLUTION: Specify encoding: read_csv('file.csv', locale = locale(encoding = 'UTF-8'))

PROBLEM 5: Large files taking too long

SOLUTION: Use n_max to read sample first, or consider data.table::fread()

PROBLEM 6: Multiple CSV files to combine

SOLUTION: Use map_dfr from purrr package files <- list.files(pattern = '.csv') data <- map_dfr(files, read_csv)

‚Äúhow to use visualization and transformation to explore your data in a systematic way‚Äù

text:

install.packages("tidyverse")

data(penguins)

Take a quick look

View(penguins)

Distributions: how values are spread out

One of the most important questions in EDA:

How do variables relate to each other?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 10. Correlation Analysis

Correlation measures how strongly two variables are related

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Step 11. Finding Outliers
Outliers are observations that are very different from others They can be:

Errors in data collection
Rare but real observations
Important discoveries!

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Answering Research Questions
EDA is about asking and answering questions!

QUESTION: Size difference between sexes?
QUESTION: Do penguins on different islands have different sizes?
QUESTION: Are bill dimensions related to body size?
QUESTION: Has penguin size changed over the years?

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Idealised Distributions

The beauty of data is that we can use samples to estimate the shape of the distribution of scores in the entire population.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Relative Frequencies

It is reasonable to assume that the relative frequencies in the sample will be similar to those in the population.
We do not need to know the actual frequencies in the population, we work instead with relative frequencies.

title: Throwing Shapes
text: Probability Distribution

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Common Distributions

Common shapes of distributions are

normal distribution,
\(t\)-distribution,
\(chi-square\) (\(\chi^2\)) distribution,
\(F\)-distribution.

Each have a specific shape that can be described by an equation.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Symmetrical/Normal Distribution

The curve is symmetrical if we draw a vertical line through the centre of the distribution then it looks the same on both sides.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Shape of the Distribution

Central Tendency: Mean determines the center of the distribution
Variability: Standard deviation width or spread of the distribution.
68-95-99.7 Rule:

68% of data falls within ¬±1œÉ of the mean.
95% within ¬±2œÉ.
99.7% within ¬±3œÉ.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Practice

Plot the Normal Distribution
Central Tendency and Variability
Visualizing Central Tendency
Interpret the Results

title: Throwing Shapes
text: All Distributions are not ‚Äúnormal‚Äù

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Real Life Data







Image source LinkedIn: Andres Vourakis

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Skewness

Skewness measures the asymmetry of a distribution around its mean.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Positive Skew

‚ÄúA longer tail on the right side.‚Äù

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Negative Skew

A longer tail on the left side.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Kurtosis

Kurtosis measures the ‚Äútailedness‚Äù or sharpness of a distribution.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Leptokurtic

Heavy tails and sharp peak.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Platykurtic

Light tails and flatter peak.

title: Throwing Shapes
text:
Practice


Skewness

Symmetric Distribution: Skewness = 0.
Positive Skew: Tail on the right; Skewness > 0.
Negative Skew: Tail on the left; Skewness < 0.


Kurtosis

Mesokurtic: Normal distribution, Kurtosis ‚âà 3.
Leptokurtic: Heavy tails, Kurtosis > 3.
Platykurtic: Light tails, Kurtosis < 3.

Data - access to original data.
Code - others can read, learn & replicate results.
Documentation - complete information about how to conduct the study.

title: Central Tendency
text:
Measures of Central Tendency

Describe the center or typical value of a dataset.



The three most common measures are:

Mean (Average).
Median (Middle value).
Mode (Most frequent value).

title: Central Tendency
text:
Mean

The mean is calculated as the sum of all data points divided by the number of points. It‚Äôs sensitive to extreme values (outliers).



\[
\bar{X} = \frac{\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^nx_i}{\displaystyle n}
\]

title: Central Tendency
text:
Median

The median is the middle value of a sorted dataset. It is robust to outliers.



If the dataset has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle values.

title: Central Tendency
text:
Mode

The mode is the most frequently occurring value in the dataset.

title: Central Tendency
text:
Problems with Mode

Unlike the mean and median, there can be no mode, one mode, or multiple modes.

title: Central Tendency
text:
Key Insights

Mean: Best for symmetric datasets but affected by outliers.
Median: Robust to outliers, useful for skewed data.
Mode: Describes the most common value, useful for categorical data.

title: Central Tendency
text: Mean the Balancing Point

title: Central Tendency
text: Effect on Mean

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Frequency Distribution


‚ÄúFrequency distribution can either be a table or a graph that shows each possible score along with the number of times that score occurred in the data.‚Äù

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Frequency Distribution

Frequency: how many times each score occurs.
If you add up the frequencies (\(\sum f\)) you get the sample size (\(N\)).
We should mention the category even if the freqency is zero.

title: Frequency Distributions
section: ü§î How does this help me to understand whether women are attracted to guys with high salaries?
text:
ü§î How does this help me to understand whether women are attracted to guys with high salaries?



Relative Frequency: How often a response is observed relative to the total number of responses.

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Relative Frequency
\[
relative\;frequency = \frac{frequency\;of\;response}{total\;number\;of\;responses}\\ = \frac{f}{N}
\]

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Relative Frequency of Rating 10
\[
relative\;frequency = \frac{frequency\;of\;rating\;10}{total\;number\;of\;responses}\\ = \frac{2}{20}\\=0.1
\]


10% of women rated a high salary‚Äôs importance at 10 out of 10.

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
ü§Ø Your Turn
Calculate Relative Frequency for score 4 on High Salary.

title: Frequency Distributions
text: Your Turn: Answer

title: Frequency Distributions
text: Cumulative Percentage

title: Frequency Distributions
text: Graphical Frequency Distributions: Histograms

title: Frequency Distributions
text: Graphical Frequency Distributions: Frequency Polygon

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Practice

Frequency table
Relative frequency table
Visualizing Relative Frequencies

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Grouped Frequency

‚Äúa frequency distribution where we group scores together‚Äù

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Grouped Frequency Distribution
\[
interval\;width = \frac{range\;of\;scores}{number\;of\;intervals}
\]

\[
= \frac{highest\;score - lowest\;score}{number\;of\;intervals}
\]

title: Frequency Distributions
text:
Relationship Assessment Score
The RAS score of 20 similar age group women are:

16, 23, 26, 22, 14, 20, 8, 19, 22, 25, 17, 26, 27, 11, 32, 17, 20, 17, 14, 28.

title: Frequency Distributions
text: 95% of them rated their relationship satisfaction lower than Alisha (32).

title: Frequency Distributions
text: References

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Theory

‚ÄúTheory is a well-established principle or set of general principles to explain a broad range of observations.‚Äù


Theory = Explanation



Source: Field (2022)

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Theory

‚Äúnormally scientists are interested in theories that apply very generally.‚Äù


Generalization



Source: Field (2022)

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Population

The population is the complete set of all individuals, items, or observations that share a common characteristic and are of interest to the researcher.
It represents everyone or everything you want to draw conclusions about.
The population has fixed parameters like the true mean (Œº) or standard deviation (œÉ), though these are often unknown and what we‚Äôre trying to estimate.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Population Examples

All registered voters in a country (if studying voting behavior)
Every student enrolled in a university (if studying student satisfaction)
All hospitals in a region (if studying healthcare quality)
The entire production line output for a year (if studying defect rates)

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Sample

A sample is a subset of the population that‚Äôs actually observed or measured in the study.
Since studying entire populations is often impractical, expensive, or impossible, researchers select a representative group to study instead.
Samples have statistics like the sample mean (xÃÑ) or sample standard deviation (s), which are used to estimate the population parameters.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Population vs Sample







Population
Sample




All registered voters in a country
1,500 randomly selected registered voters


Every student enrolled in a university
300 students chosen from different departments


All hospitals in a region
50 hospitals selected using stratified sampling


The entire production line output for a year
500 randomly selected products from the production line

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Statistical Inference

The goal of most research is statistical inference: using sample statistics to make educated guesses about population parameters.
The quality of your sample determines how well you can generalize findings back to the population.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Hypothesis

A hypothesis is a testable statement or prediction about the relationship between variables in a population.
It‚Äôs essentially an educated guess based on theory, prior research, or observation that you‚Äôre trying to verify or refute using data from your sample.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
section: How Hypothesis Connects to Population and Sample
text:
How Hypothesis Connects to Population and Sample

Hypothesis is about the population: Your hypothesis makes a claim about the entire population (all students, all patients, etc.), even though you can‚Äôt study everyone.
Sample provides the evidence: You collect data from your sample to test whether the evidence supports or contradicts the null hypothesis.
Statistical inference bridges the gap: You use statistical tests to determine whether the patterns you observe in your sample are strong enough to conclude something about the population.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Variables
‚ÄúElements in the study that are measured or manipulated.‚Äù

Independent variable
Dependent variable

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Statistical Learning
‚ÄúStatistical Learning refers to a vast set of tools for understanding data.‚Äù


Descriptive StatisticsInferential Statistics



Summarizes and organizes data to describe its main features.
Makes predictions or inferences about a population from a sample.




Limited to the observed data.
Goes beyond the observed data to infer population characteristics.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Sampling Variation

These statistics vary from one sample to the next.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Sampling Error

These statistics sometimes differ from the population parameter.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Simple Maths
\[
1 + 2\times3^2
\]

Answer: 19

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
BODMAS

Brackets
Order (Power)
Divide
Multiplication
Addition
Subtraction

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
section: What will be the answer to this?
text:
What will be the answer to this?
\[
10 + \frac{2(3+1)^2}{8} - 5
\]

\[
10 + \frac{2\times16}{8} - 5
\]


Answer: 9

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Let‚Äôs Understand this
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n x_i
\]

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Let‚Äôs Understand this
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n x_i \\ = 10 + 6 \\ = 16
\]

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Let‚Äôs Try this
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n x^2_i
\]

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Let‚Äôs Try this
\[
\left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \right )^2
\]

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Let‚Äôs Try this
\[
\left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \right )^2 \\ = (10+6)^2 \\ = 16^2 \\ = 256
\]

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Scales of measurement

Scales of measurement (also called levels of measurement) classify how variables are measured and what mathematical operations can be performed on them.
There are four main scales:

Nominal scale.
Ordinal scale.
Interval scale.
Ratio scale.

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Nominal Scale

Categories with no inherent order or ranking.
Categories are different but not better/worse or higher/lower
Examples:

Gender (male, female, non-binary)
Blood type (A, B, AB, O)
Marital status (single, married, divorced, widowed)
Eye color (blue, brown, green, hazel)
Type of car (sedan, SUV, truck)

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Ordinal Scale

Categories with a meaningful order or ranking, but the intervals between ranks are not equal or known.
You can rank items from lowest to highest
Examples:

Education level (high school, bachelor‚Äôs, master‚Äôs, doctorate)
Satisfaction ratings (very dissatisfied, dissatisfied, neutral, satisfied, very satisfied)
Socioeconomic status (lower class, middle class, upper class)
Military ranks (private, corporal, sergeant, lieutenant)
Pain scale (mild, moderate, severe)

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Interval Scale

Ordered categories with equal intervals between values, but no true zero point.
Equal distances between consecutive values
Examples:

Temperature in Celsius or Fahrenheit (0¬∞ doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúno temperature‚Äù)
IQ scores (an IQ of 0 doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúno intelligence‚Äù)
Standardized test scores (SAT, GRE)

title: Foundational Concepts in Statistical Research
text:
Ratio Scale

Ordered categories with equal intervals AND a true/absolute zero point, where zero means complete absence of the quantity.
Examples:

Height (0 cm = no height)
Weight (0 kg = no weight)
Age (0 years = just born)
Income (0 dollars = no money)
Number of children (0 = no children)
